Award.AwardTitle: RUI Ramifications of Ethanol Usage as a Biofuel: Quantifying Sources and Impacts on the Light Absorbing Properties of Rainwater
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to investigate the atmospheric chemistry of ethanol and the impacts of increasing levels ethanol production centered on its use as a gasoline fuel additive. Colored dissolved organic matter (CDOM) is another potential environmental source having impact on the concentration of ethanol in rainwater. Preliminary data suggests that ethanol can be produced by photolysis of rainwater after short (~4 hour) exposure to simulated sunlight.

These RUI (Research at Undergraduate Institution) PIs have previously shown that there is a measurable concentration difference of ethanol in precipitation samples collected in sites from Wilmington NC and in Sao Paulo Brazil. The concentrations of ethanol in rainwater vary significantly between rain events, with higher concentrations occurring during storms associated with continental air masses. High concentrations of ethanol in precipitation are said to influence the oxidizing capacity of the atmosphere and may have indirect effects on solar radiative transfer and climate.

The project seeks to answer three related questions:
1)What are the relative proportions of biofuel and naturally derived ethanol in ambient rainwater?
2)What are the impacts of photolysed ethanol on the chromophoric properties of rainwater?
3) What are the reaction pathways and molecular level compositional changes responsible for changes in CDOM abundance and photochemical lability upon ethanol production?

POR.DRECONTENT:
The use of ethanol as a biofuel is increasing worldwide as it is a renewable transportation fuel with a potentially lower carbon dioxide footprint compared to fossil fuels.  Some fraction of fuel ethanol is emitted directly to the atmosphere where it can contribute to smog and ozone formation resulting in lower air quality. The primary objective of this research was to determine the relative importance of this vehicle source of ethanol compared to biogenic or plant emissions of the alcohol to the atmosphere.  Delineating the significance of anthropogenic sources to atmospheric concentrations is vital when debating the viability of current as well as future global biofuel mandates.

During the course of this study we have evaluated the ethanol content in rainwater collected from 14 sites in 6 different countries including several such as the US, Australia, and China which use 10% ethanol as fuel and Japan which uses less than 1% ethanol blended in fuel and Greece which does not use ethanol as fuel. Using a two end-member mixing model developed during this research, our results indicate that vehicles contribute from 11% to 97% of the ethanol in rainwater collected in North Carolina with an average biofuel contribution of 73%. The average biofuel contribution was over five times higher than previously predicted in modeled global ethanol inventories which is significant because it suggests that the concentration of ethanol in the atmosphere will increase steadily as our use of biofuels increases. 

The very detailed Wilmington NC, USA ethanol data set also allowed us to examine the correlation between vehicle usage and atmospheric concentrations. Results indicated that the use of ethanol, which has more than doubled in the preceding decade, has resulted in a four-fold increase in the abundance of atmospheric ethanol (in both air and rainwater) over eight years consistent with the relatively high vehicle contribution described above. Gas phase ethanol concentrations measured near a variety of roadways also correlated positively with road density (m of road per km2 of land) in Wilmington underscoring the importance of anthropogenic sources to tropospheric concentrations. Results of this study indicated that the impact of vehicles on atmospheric ethanol may be relatively local as concentrations are elevated by a factor of 10 near major roadways but return to background levels within 20 m of the road.

The research conducted during this award significantly enhanced the recruiting of young students in critical science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) fields because it examined very relevant questions at the interface of environmental concerns and societal needs. This experience ultimately motivated these young students to continue their education and choose science as a career. The PIs also performed much public outreach during this award including serving as program coordinator for the chemistry section of the Science Olympiad and as judges in Regional Science fairs.  Our research team has also participated in a variety of outreach activities to summer science programs including a series of six chemistry camps held each year and presentations made by our graduate students to Marine Science summer camp programs.
